answers.answer: There are several ways to enter Romania, including with temporary protection, with the right of short-stay, or as an asylum seeker. You can also apply for asylum within Romania at a later point.
answers.instruction: Go to website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read the page carefully.

answers.answer: You can enter Romania from Ukraine using the Halmeu, Sighetu Marmației, Siret, Rădăuți-Prut, and Isaccea border points. Alternatively, you can also reach Romania through the Republic of Moldova.
answers.instruction: Go to website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read the section under 'Border crossing From Ukraine'.

answers.answer: Ukrainian nationals can enter Romania on a short stay status by presenting a valid passport. If you do not have a passport, you can still enter by asking for asylum at the border. For minors, it is advisable to carry an identity document or a birth certificate.
answers.instruction: Go to website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read the section under 'Identity documents'.

answers.answer: NGOs are present at border crossings to help people with food and guidance. For questions about access into Romania, you can also call the National Council for Refugees (CNRR) at +40 730 073 170.
answers.instruction: Go to website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read the page carefully.

answers.answer: You can bring your animal to Romania even if it is not vaccinated against rabies or not identified with a microchip/tattoo. As the owner, you must fill in the Pet Location Form and complete all necessary formalities after entering Romania.
answers.instruction: Go to website https://dopomoha.ro/en/entering-romania and read the section under 'Animals'.
